attributes.comment:
I am appalled that USCIS has proposed such massive fee increases. I have been
practicing immigration law since 1986. Each time there has been a fee increase
there has been no corresponding improvement in service. Instead, processing
times get longer and adjudications get more inconsistent. As just one example,
the latest so-called ?improvement? of bi-specialization has replaced a processing
time of approximately 60-90 days for an EB-1 multinational manager I-140 at VSC
with approximately 1 year at NSC. And, I have some applicants for I-485s and N-
400s who have been waiting for more than 1 year for ?security clearances.? USCIS
has made it impossible to get useful or accurate information when there is a
problem by requiring people to call an ?800? number. The ?customer service?
representatives read from scripts, ask irrelevant questions (such as the birth date
of a petitioner?s representative) and do nothing more than look at the same case
status system that we can access ourselves. I cannot count the number of times
these ?customer service? people have given my clients a wrong answer. USCIS
could save money if it would allow us to resolve problems by speaking with
officers at the Service Centers, as we used to do. The ?new? USCIS web site is
full of broken "links" and much harder to use than the original one. If I am having
problems finding information - and I know what I am looking for on the site - I can
imagine how difficult it is for the general public. A fee increase from $190 to
$320 for an I-129 imposes a further burden on U.S. businesses who want to
remain competitive in the global market place by hiring both U.S. and foreign
workers. Increasing the fee for a Form I-485 from $325 to $905 places a ?green
card? out of reach for most people. I cannot help but wonder if a fee increase from
$330 to $595 for the N-400 is intended to discourage an increase in the number of
foreign born U.S. citizens. Our country has benefited from being a nation of
immigrants. These fee increases send the message that the foreign-born are not
welcome here. Before USCIS proposes fee increases, it needs to prove that the
funds will be used to improve service and that it will have people who are trained
properly to help customers and adjudicate their petitions and applications fairly
and consistently. Until then, this proposed rulemaking should be withdrawn.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Leslie Dellon
